title: HIV-Associated Neurocognitive Disorder
icd10: F02.80 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere without behavioral disturbance)
F02.81 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere with behavioral disturbance)
F06.8 (Other specified mental disorders due to known physiological condition)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of the HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) spectrum including asymptomatic neurocognitive impairment (ANI), mild neurocognitive disorder (MND), and HIV-associated dementia (HAD) per Frascati criteria. Covers ART optimization with emphasis on CNS penetration effectiveness (CPE score), exclusion of opportunistic infections, neuropsychological testing, management of comorbid depression and substance use, and monitoring for disease progression. Settings: ED (acute presentations), HOSP (inpatient evaluation), OPD (outpatient longitudinal management). Excludes CNS opportunistic infections as primary diagnosis (see separate templates for PML, CMV encephalitis, toxoplasmosis, cryptococcal meningitis), acute HIV seroconversion encephalitis, and pediatric HIV neurocognitive impairment.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Confirm HIV diagnosis if not previously documented; baseline for new presentations
Immune status determines HAND risk stratification; CD4 <200 increases risk of HAD and opportunistic infections; CD4 nadir is strongest predictor of HAND
Plasma virologic control; detectable viral load associated with worse neurocognitive outcomes; assess ART adherence
Anemia (ZDV), infection, hematologic abnormalities; macrocytosis may indicate medication effect or B12/folate deficiency
Metabolic encephalopathy; hepatic dysfunction (hepatitis co-infection); renal function for ART dosing; electrolyte abnormalities
Neurosyphilis co-infection common in HIV population; treatable cause of cognitive decline; higher rate of neurosyphilis in HIV+ patients
Essential/Core Labs.target: Nonreactive; if reactive, obtain LP for neurosyphilis

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypothyroidism is reversible cause of cognitive impairment; efavirenz and immune reconstitution can affect thyroid
B12 deficiency common in HIV; causes cognitive impairment and myelopathy; reversible
Folate deficiency contributes to cognitive decline; TMP-SMX prophylaxis may mask deficiency
Co-infection screening; hepatitis affects ART selection; hepatic encephalopathy in differential

Essential/Core Labs.item: Hepatitis C antibody + RNA if positive (CPT 86803)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: HCV co-infection prevalence 25-30% in HIV; HCV independently causes neurocognitive impairment; treatable
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive, obtain HCV RNA and initiate treatment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: UTI as cause of acute cognitive worsening; tenofovir nephrotoxicity screening
Substance use is major confounder and comorbidity in HAND evaluation; methamphetamine, cocaine, and opioids cause neurocognitive impairment; must be excluded before HAND diagnosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive result requires addressing substance use before attributing deficits to HAND

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If virologic failure suspected; resistance mutations affect ART optimization for CNS-penetrating regimen
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Wild-type preferred; document resistance mutations for CNS-penetrating ART selection

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Diabetes independently impairs cognition; metabolic syndrome common with ART (PIs); vascular risk factor
Cardiovascular risk factors contribute to vascular cognitive impairment; PI-associated dyslipidemia
Hypogonadism common in HIV; causes fatigue, depression, and cognitive symptoms; treatable
Deficiency common in HIV; associated with cognitive decline; TDF and efavirenz may worsen
Wernicke encephalopathy if alcohol use; nutritional deficiency common in HIV
Hepatic encephalopathy if liver disease (HBV/HCV co-infection, cirrhosis)
Baseline serostatus; if positive, at risk for reactivation with CD4 <100; mass lesion in differential
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Document serostatus; negative reduces toxoplasmosis risk

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Screen if CD4 <100; cryptococcal meningitis causes cognitive impairment; may be subclinical
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive requires LP and treatment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Baseline serostatus; CMV encephalitis risk if CD4 <50
Depression prevalence 20-40% in HIV; major confounder in cognitive assessment; treatable; must be addressed before HAND diagnosis

Specialized Testing (Selected Patients).rationale: If CNS penetration or adherence concerns; especially for dolutegravir, darunavir CSF levels in suspected CNS escape
Wilson disease if <50 years with movement disorder and cognitive decline
Autoimmune process in differential; HIV can cause false-positive ANA
If subacute onset with concern for HIV-associated malignancy (lymphoma)
PML risk stratification; positive serostatus with CD4 <200 increases PML risk
If subacute cognitive decline with psychiatric features, seizures; immune reconstitution may trigger autoimmune processes

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in cryptococcal meningitis, mass lesions; normal in uncomplicated HAND
Lumbar Puncture.target: 10-20 cm H2O; elevated requires evaluation for OI

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Mild CSF pleocytosis (5-20 WBC) can be seen in HIV alone; higher counts suggest OI or co-infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC <20 in HAND; WBC >20 requires aggressive OI investigation

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Mildly elevated (50-100 mg/dL) common in HAND; markedly elevated suggests OI or other pathology
Lumbar Puncture.target: 15-45 mg/dL normal; mild elevation expected in HAND

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low CSF glucose suggests bacterial/fungal/TB meningitis; normal in HAND
Lumbar Puncture.target: >60% of serum glucose; low requires evaluation for OI

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF viral escape (detectable CSF HIV RNA with suppressed plasma viral load) is treatable cause of HAND; guides ART optimization for CNS penetration
Lumbar Puncture.target: Undetectable; if detectable with suppressed plasma VL, this indicates CSF viral escape requiring ART optimization for CNS penetration

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Neurosyphilis; VDRL is only validated non-treponemal CSF test; high co-infection rate
Rule out cryptococcal meningitis if CD4 <200 or elevated opening pressure; can present with subacute cognitive decline
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; positive requires cryptococcal meningitis treatment

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out viral encephalitis (HSV, CMV, VZV, JC virus); especially if acute/subacute presentation
PML if white matter lesions on MRI; CD4 <200; progressive multifocal symptoms
CMV encephalitis if CD4 <50; periventricular enhancement on MRI

Lumbar Puncture.item: AFB smear and culture, TB PCR (CPT 87116, 87556)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Tuberculous meningitis if endemic area, low CD4, constitutional symptoms
CNS lymphoma if mass lesion, EBV+ in CSF; HIV increases lymphoma risk
Primary CNS lymphoma marker; elevated CSF EBV DNA with ring-enhancing lesion on MRI
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; positive with enhancing lesion requires biopsy or empiric treatment

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Marker of neuronal injury; elevated in active HAND; may track treatment response; research and specialized centers
Lumbar Puncture.target: Low/normal; elevated indicates active neuronal injury

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Intrathecal immune activation; elevated in HAND but nonspecific; helps distinguish from MS or other inflammatory processes

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Initial evaluation of all suspected HAND; contrast to evaluate for OI, lymphoma, or other enhancing lesions
Essential/First-line.target: HAND: cerebral atrophy (esp. caudate, basal ganglia), white matter hyperintensities, no enhancing lesions; ring-enhancing lesions indicate toxoplasmosis vs lymphoma; multifocal white matter lesions without enhancement indicate PML

Essential/First-line.timing: Emergent evaluation if MRI unavailable; acute mental status change; mass effect evaluation before LP
Essential/First-line.target: Mass lesion, hydrocephalus, hemorrhage; less sensitive than MRI for HAND-specific changes

Extended.timing: Research/specialized centers; differentiating HAND from other dementias; monitoring treatment response
Extended.target: HAND: elevated choline/creatine (inflammation), reduced N-acetylaspartate/creatine (neuronal loss), elevated myoinositol (gliosis); pattern may precede structural changes

Extended.timing: Diagnostic uncertainty; differentiate HAND from AD or FTD; atypical presentations
Extended.target: HAND: subcortical hypometabolism (basal ganglia, thalamus); AD: temporoparietal; FTD: frontal

Extended.timing: If concern for systemic OI, lymphoma, or other HIV-associated malignancy as cause of CNS symptoms
If seizures suspected, subclinical seizure activity, or NCSE in acute cognitive decline
Extended.target: HAND: generalized slowing; focal abnormalities indicate structural lesion; seizure activity requires treatment

Neuropsychological Testing.timing: All patients at initial evaluation; MoCA preferred (more sensitive for subcortical deficits)
Neuropsychological Testing.indication: Screening; MoCA more sensitive than MMSE for HAND (subcortical pattern)

Neuropsychological Testing.timing: Rapid bedside screen validated for HIV; assesses psychomotor speed, memory, construction
Alternative bedside screen; culturally adapted; less education bias than HDS
Gold standard for HAND diagnosis per Frascati criteria; must test >=5 cognitive domains; quantifies severity across domains
Neuropsychological Testing.indication: Definitive HAND classification; required for Frascati diagnosis; baseline for monitoring treatment response

Neuropsychological Testing.timing: Required for Frascati classification; distinguishes ANI (no impairment) from MND (mild) and HAD (marked)
Neuropsychological Testing.indication: Determine functional impact of cognitive deficits

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: First-line INSTI with high CPE score (CPE 4); excellent CNS penetration; backbone of CNS-optimized ART regimen

dosing.instructions: 50 mg PO daily; increase to 50 mg BID if INSTI resistance suspected or with rifampin

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: Viral load q4-8 weeks until undetectable, then q3-6 months; CD4 q3-6 months; CMP; weight gain monitoring

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: NRTI backbone; TAF with moderate CPE; preferred over TDF for renal/bone safety

dosing.instructions: 1 tablet PO daily

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: CrCl <30 (for combined formulation); concurrent use with other tenofovir products
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: Renal function; lipid panel; HBV status (flare risk if discontinued)

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: Alternative NRTI backbone; TDF has slightly higher CPE than TAF

doseOptions.orderSentence: Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) / Emtricitabine (Truvada) 300/200 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 1 tablet PO daily; dose adjust for CrCl <50
dosing.orderSentence: Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) / Emtricitabine (Truvada) 300/200 mg PO

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: Renal function q3-6 months; DEXA if >50 or risk factors; phosphorus

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: NRTI with high CPE score (CPE 3); use in CNS-optimized regimens

dosing.instructions: 600 mg PO daily or 300 mg BID

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: **HLA-B*5701 positive** (fatal hypersensitivity reaction -- must test before prescribing); cardiovascular risk (controversial)
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: HLA-B*5701 mandatory before initiation; hypersensitivity reaction monitoring

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: NRTI with highest CPE score (CPE 4); use in CNS-escape despite toxicity; historical backbone of HAND treatment

dosing.instructions: 300 mg PO BID; dose adjust for renal impairment

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: CBC q2-4 weeks initially (anemia, neutropenia); CK if myopathy symptoms; macrocytosis expected

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: PI with moderate CPE; boosted PI for resistant virus; use when INSTI resistance present

dosing.instructions: 800 mg darunavir + 100 mg ritonavir PO daily with food; 600/100 mg BID if resistance

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy (relative); concurrent drugs with CYP3A4 interactions
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: LFTs; lipid panel; glucose; drug interactions (extensive CYP3A4 inhibition); GI tolerance

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: NNRTI with high CPE score (CPE 3); historical use in HAND; CNS side effects limit utility due to neuropsychiatric toxicity

dosing.instructions: 600 mg PO at bedtime on empty stomach

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: Pregnancy (first trimester -- teratogenic); severe psychiatric disease; concurrent CYP interactions
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: **Neuropsychiatric monitoring** (vivid dreams, depression, suicidality, psychosis -- especially first 2-4 weeks); LFTs; lipid panel

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: NNRTI with high CPE score (CPE 4); alternative for CNS optimization; hepatotoxicity and rash risk limit use

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO daily x 14 days lead-in, then 200 mg BID; extended release: 400 mg daily after lead-in

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: CD4 >250 (women) or >400 (men) for treatment-naive (hepatotoxicity risk); severe hepatic impairment
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 2 wks, 4 wks, then q3 months; rash monitoring (SJS risk first 18 weeks); discontinue if LFTs >5x ULN

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.indication: CCR5 antagonist with high CPE score (CPE 3); requires tropism testing; unique anti-inflammatory CNS mechanism relevant to HAND

dosing.instructions: 300 mg PO BID (with CYP3A4 inhibitors: 150 mg BID; with inducers: 600 mg BID)

ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.contraindications: Non-CCR5-tropic virus (must confirm R5 tropism before use); hepatotoxicity risk
ART Optimization for CNS Penetration.monitoring: Tropism assay mandatory; LFTs; cough, URI symptoms; CYP3A4 interactions

Treatment of CSF Viral Escape.indication: CSF viral escape (detectable CSF HIV RNA with suppressed plasma viral load); neurologic deterioration despite plasma viral suppression

dosing.instructions: Switch to regimen with highest total CPE score incorporating dolutegravir + 2 high-CPE NRTIs (e.g., DTG/ABC/3TC or DTG + ZDV/3TC); target total CPE >=7-8; guided by resistance profile

Treatment of CSF Viral Escape.monitoring: Repeat LP in 4-8 weeks to confirm CSF viral suppression; plasma VL q4 weeks; neuropsychological retesting at 6-12 months

Treatment of CSF Viral Escape.indication: Multidrug-resistant CSF viral escape refractory to oral optimization; extensive NRTI/NNRTI/PI/INSTI resistance

dosing.instructions: 90 mg SC BID (injection site rotation)

Treatment of CSF Viral Escape.monitoring: Injection site reactions; pneumonia risk; eosinophilia; CSF VL follow-up

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Depression comorbid with HAND (prevalence 20-40%); safe in HIV; minimal drug interactions with ART

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25 mg q1-2 weeks; target 50-200 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; caution with ritonavir (increases sertraline levels)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring; serotonin syndrome; GI effects; hyponatremia

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Depression/anxiety comorbid with HAND; well tolerated; minimal CYP interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg daily; max 20 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; suicidality monitoring; check interactions with PIs

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Depression with insomnia and weight loss (common in HIV); appetite stimulation; dual benefit in HIV wasting with depression

dosing.instructions: Start 15 mg QHS; increase to 30-45 mg; lower dose more sedating

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; caution with CYP3A4 inhibitors (PIs may increase levels)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Weight gain (desired in wasting); sedation; neutropenia (rare)

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Depression with fatigue, psychomotor slowing; avoid in seizure risk; may assist with stimulant cessation in comorbid methamphetamine use

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg XL daily; increase to 300 mg XL daily after 1 week if needed

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Seizure disorder; eating disorders; concurrent MAOIs; abrupt alcohol/benzodiazepine withdrawal
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Seizure risk; insomnia; anxiety; blood pressure

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Psychomotor slowing, apathy, and fatigue in HAND; evidence for improved attention and processing speed in HIV cognitive impairment; [Hinkin et al., J Neuropsychiatry Clin Neurosci 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11449032/)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID (morning and noon); increase by 5-10 mg/week; target 20-40 mg/day in divided doses; avoid evening dosing

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; cardiac arrhythmias; glaucoma; concurrent MAOIs; active psychosis; substance abuse history (relative)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Heart rate; blood pressure; appetite; insomnia; psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Fatigue and excessive daytime sleepiness in HAND; alternative to methylphenidate with lower abuse potential

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg QAM; increase to 200 mg QAM after 1 week; max 200 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; cardiac arrhythmias; concurrent CYP3A4 concerns (may reduce PI levels -- monitor)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; interactions with PIs (may reduce darunavir levels); sleep quality; SJS risk (rare)

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: NMDA receptor-mediated neurotoxicity in HIV; moderate-severe HAND; limited but emerging evidence for neuroprotection in HAND; [Schifitto et al., AIDS 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17721095/)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5 mg/week to 10 mg BID; max 20 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Insomnia comorbid with HAND; sleep disruption common in HIV; alternative to benzodiazepines (avoid in HAND)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg QHS; titrate to 50-100 mg QHS as needed; max 100 mg QHS for insomnia

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Orthostatic hypotension; concurrent MAOIs; priapism risk

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Agitation, psychosis, or severe behavioral disturbance in HAD; lowest effective dose; use non-pharmacologic interventions first

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg QHS; titrate slowly to lowest effective dose; max 100-200 mg for behavioral symptoms in dementia

Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: **Caution: metabolic effects compound ART metabolic toxicity**; QTc; glucose; lipids; weight; EPS monitoring

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Acute agitation or psychosis in ED/inpatient setting with HAD; short-term use only

dosing.instructions: 2-5 mg IV/IM PRN; may repeat q30min; max 20 mg/24h; switch to oral atypical ASAP

Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: QTc before and during use; EPS; NMS monitoring; avoid in DLB (not typical in HAND)

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.indication: Opioid use disorder comorbid with HAND; improves ART adherence; minimal cognitive impairment vs. continued illicit use

dosing.instructions: Induction: 2/0.5 mg SL; increase by 2/0.5-4/1 mg q1-2h to relief; target maintenance 8/2-16/4 mg daily

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.contraindications: Concurrent full agonist opioids (precipitated withdrawal); severe hepatic impairment
Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.monitoring: LFTs; precipitated withdrawal; sedation; check interactions with PIs (buprenorphine levels may increase with ritonavir)

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.indication: Alcohol use disorder comorbid with HAND; alcohol worsens cognitive impairment and ART non-adherence

dosing.instructions: 380 mg IM gluteal injection monthly; patient must be opioid-free >=7-10 days

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.contraindications: Acute opioid use; acute hepatitis; hepatic failure
Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.monitoring: LFTs; injection site reaction; depression screening; opioid-free confirmation

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.indication: Methamphetamine use disorder (most common stimulant in HIV-HAND population); no FDA-approved pharmacotherapy; CM has strongest evidence

dosing.instructions: Refer to behavioral health program offering contingency management/motivational incentives; combine with cognitive behavioral therapy

Substance Use Treatment (Common Comorbid.monitoring: Adherence; UDS; neurocognitive monitoring for improvement after abstinence

Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.indication: PCP prophylaxis if CD4 <200; toxoplasmosis prophylaxis if CD4 <100 and Toxo IgG+; prevents OIs that worsen cognition

dosing.instructions: 1 DS tablet (160/800 mg) PO daily; alternatives: dapsone, atovaquone if sulfa allergy

Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; severe renal impairment; folate deficiency (supplement)
Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.monitoring: CBC; CMP; rash (SJS rare); hyperkalemia; folate supplementation

Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.indication: Secondary prophylaxis if prior cryptococcal meningitis; maintenance until immune reconstitution (CD4 >200 x 6 months)

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO daily until CD4 >200 for >=6 months on suppressive ART

Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.contraindications: Hepatic disease; QT prolongation; drug interactions (azoles + PIs)
Prophylaxis Against Opportunistic Infect.monitoring: LFTs; drug interactions with ART (especially ritonavir); QTc

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease/HIV specialist for ART optimization with focus on CNS-penetrating regimen and resistance management
Neurology consultation for HAND diagnosis confirmation, exclusion of other etiologies, and longitudinal cognitive monitoring
Neuropsychology for formal neuropsychological testing (mandatory for Frascati criteria diagnosis); minimum 5 cognitive domains assessed
Psychiatry for depression, anxiety, PTSD management (prevalence 20-40% in HIV); substance use disorder treatment
Addiction medicine / substance use treatment if active substance use; methamphetamine use is most potent modifier of HAND
Social work for medication adherence support, housing stability, insurance navigation, disability applications; social determinants profoundly affect HAND outcomes
Case management / HIV navigator for ART adherence programs (DOT, pill boxes, pharmacy sync); adherence is the single most modifiable factor in HAND treatment
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and compensatory strategies in MND/HAD; adaptive equipment; vocational rehabilitation
Speech therapy if language or swallowing difficulties in advanced HAD
Palliative care for advanced HAD with poor prognosis despite optimized ART; goals of care discussions
Ophthalmology if CD4 <100 for CMV retinitis screening; vision changes in HAND evaluation

Patient/Family Instructions.item: ART adherence is the most important factor in preventing and treating HAND; undetectable viral load = healthiest brain; use pill organizers, alarms, and pharmacy reminders
Cognitive difficulties in HIV are treatable -- ART optimization often improves symptoms over months; do not stop medications
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs; substances worsen cognitive impairment independently and reduce ART adherence; methamphetamine is particularly neurotoxic
Report new or worsening memory problems, confusion, difficulty with daily tasks, personality changes, or depression to your HIV provider promptly
Establish healthcare proxy and advance directives, particularly if diagnosed with HAD; discuss preferences while able to participate
Keep all follow-up appointments; cognitive monitoring requires regular neuropsychological testing to track changes over time
Return to ED if sudden confusion, severe headache, fever with cognitive changes, new weakness, seizures, or vision changes (may indicate OI, not just HAND)
Sleep hygiene: maintain consistent sleep schedule; insomnia worsens cognitive function and is treatable
Exercise regularly (30 min moderate activity, 5 days/week); physical activity improves cognition in HIV; [Fazeli et al., J Neurovirol 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24554483/)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 min, 5 days/week) -- improves neurocognition, cardiovascular health, mood, and immune function in HIV
Cognitive stimulation activities (reading, puzzles, social engagement, learning new skills); preserves cognitive reserve
Mediterranean or MIND diet; cardiovascular risk reduction contributes to brain health; nutritional optimization in HIV
Cardiovascular risk factor management (BP <130/80, diabetes control, lipid management); vascular contributions to HAND increasingly recognized
Tobacco cessation (smoking rate >40% in PLWH); smoking accelerates brain aging and vascular cognitive impairment
Limit alcohol to <=1 drink/day or abstain; alcohol is directly neurotoxic and worsens HIV-mediated neuroinflammation
Avoid benzodiazepines and anticholinergics; these worsen cognitive impairment and must be minimized in HAND patients
Social engagement and peer support groups (PLWH community); social isolation worsens depression and cognitive decline
Screen for and treat obstructive sleep apnea; prevalence increased in HIV; untreated OSA worsens cognition

differential.diagnosis: CNS opportunistic infection (toxoplasmosis, cryptococcal meningitis, PML, CMV encephalitis)
differential.features: Acute/subacute onset; focal deficits; fever; low CD4 (<200 typically); enhancing or white matter lesions on MRI
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; LP with OI panel; serum/CSF cryptococcal antigen; CSF JC virus PCR; toxoplasma serology

differential.features: Depressed mood; "I don't know" responses; subjective complaints often exceed objective deficits; rapid onset; sleep/appetite changes; may not show >=2 domain deficits on testing
differential.tests: PHQ-9; psychiatric evaluation; neuropsychological testing (depression affects effort-dependent tasks but spares recognition); trial of antidepressant with cognitive reassessment

differential.diagnosis: Substance use effects (methamphetamine, cocaine, opioids, alcohol)
differential.features: Temporal correlation with substance use; positive UDS; may improve with sustained abstinence; methamphetamine causes similar subcortical deficits as HAND
differential.tests: UDS; history; reassess cognition after >=4 weeks abstinence; brain MRI (meth causes white matter changes similar to HAND)

differential.features: Co-infection common; Argyll Robertson pupils; may be indistinguishable from HAND clinically; posterior column signs in tabes
differential.tests: Serum RPR/VDRL; CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS; treat with IV penicillin and reassess

differential.features: HBV/HCV co-infection; asterixis; elevated ammonia; fluctuating consciousness; cirrhosis on exam
differential.tests: Ammonia level; LFTs; hepatitis serologies; abdominal imaging

differential.features: Ring-enhancing periventricular lesion; progressive focal deficits; CD4 typically <50; EBV-associated
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF EBV PCR; stereotactic biopsy; whole body PET

differential.features: Temporal relation to drug initiation; efavirenz (neuropsychiatric), dolutegravir (insomnia), opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics
differential.tests: Medication timeline; trial discontinuation; drug levels; symptoms reverse with discontinuation

differential.features: Cortical pattern (aphasia, apraxia, agnosia); prominent episodic memory loss with poor recognition; older patient; amyloid biomarkers positive
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing (cortical vs subcortical pattern); amyloid PET or CSF Abeta42/tau; MRI (hippocampal atrophy in AD vs caudate atrophy in HAND)

differential.features: Stepwise decline; cardiovascular risk factors; strategic infarcts; white matter disease on MRI; may coexist with HAND
differential.tests: MRI (lacunar infarcts, extensive WMH); vascular risk factor assessment; HAND and VCI may be additive

differential.features: Acute/fluctuating; electrolyte abnormalities; renal failure; medication-related
differential.tests: CMP; renal function; glucose; corrects with metabolic correction

differential.features: Paradoxical worsening after ART initiation (typically 2-8 weeks); new or worsening neurological symptoms; enhancing lesions
differential.tests: Timing correlation with ART start; MRI with contrast; LP; distinguish from OI vs IRIS; may require corticosteroids
Urgent imaging followed by LP followed by empiric treatment
Urgent MRI with contrast; initiate empiric toxoplasmosis treatment if ring-enhancing lesion
CT head followed by labs followed by LP; seizure management
MRI; LP; initiate corticosteroids for IRIS; do not stop ART

differential.diagnosis: CD4 <100 with new headache or confusion
differential.tests: Serum CrAg; urgent imaging followed by LP; empiric treatment

differential.features: CMV retinitis; PML affecting occipital lobe; optic neuritis

evidence.recommendation: Frascati criteria define HAND classification (ANI, MND, HAD) based on neuropsychological testing in >=5 domains
HAND prevalence remains 30-50% despite effective ART; ANI is most common form in ART era
CD4 nadir is strongest predictor of HAND regardless of current CD4
CSF viral escape occurs in 5-10% of virologically suppressed patients; treatable with CNS-penetrating ART
Higher CPE score ART regimens associated with better CSF viral suppression
CPE score does not consistently predict neurocognitive improvement (controversy exists)
Dolutegravir achieves therapeutic CSF concentrations and has high CPE score
ART initiation improves neurocognitive function in most patients; greatest benefit in first 6-12 months
evidence.source: Wright et al. (SMART/START neurocognitive substudies) -- unable to verify specific PMID; see [Wright et al. AIDS 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29424786/) for START neurocognitive substudy

evidence.recommendation: Depression and substance use are major confounders in HAND diagnosis and must be addressed
evidence.source: [Mind Exchange Working Group. Clin Infect Dis 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23175555/)

evidence.recommendation: Methamphetamine use compounds HIV neurotoxicity and accelerates HAND progression
Methylphenidate improves psychomotor speed and attention in HIV cognitive impairment
evidence.source: [Hinkin et al. J Neuropsychiatry Clin Neurosci 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11449032/)

evidence.recommendation: Exercise improves neurocognitive outcomes in people living with HIV
HCV co-infection independently worsens neurocognitive impairment in HIV
AAN and EACS recommend neurocognitive screening for all PLWH
Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) can cause paradoxical neurologic worsening after ART initiation

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months on stable ART; q4 weeks during ART changes
monitoring.action: Detectable: perform adherence assessment, resistance testing, ART modification

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months until immune reconstitution (CD4 >500 x 2 years); then annually
monitoring.action: <200: initiate OI prophylaxis; <100: high risk for OIs affecting cognition

monitoring.item: CSF HIV RNA (if initial CSF escape)
monitoring.frequency: 4-8 weeks after ART optimization; then q6-12 months if history of CSF escape
monitoring.action: Persistent CSF viral escape: perform further ART optimization; initiate salvage regimen; neurology/ID co-management

monitoring.frequency: Every clinic visit or at minimum q6 months
monitoring.action: Decline >=2 points: obtain formal neuropsychological testing; evaluate for new confounders

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; 6-12 months after ART optimization; annually in MND/HAD; q2 years in ANI
monitoring.action: Worsening: obtain CSF evaluation for viral escape; imaging; confounder assessment
>=10: initiate/adjust antidepressant; >=20: urgent psychiatric referral; suicidality assessment
Active use: initiate substance use treatment referral; reassess HAND diagnosis after abstinence
Suboptimal: identify barriers; case management; DOT; simplify regimen; adherence counseling
Decline: increase support; OT referral; driving evaluation; reassess HAND severity

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; repeat if clinical worsening, suspected OI, or CSF escape detected
monitoring.action: New enhancement: perform OI workup; progressive atrophy: evaluate treatment failure; WMH progression: initiate vascular management
Metabolic syndrome: initiate cardiovascular risk reduction; address vascular contribution to cognitive impairment

disposition.criteria: Suspected ANI or MND; stable cognition; safe home environment; reliable follow-up; no acute OI concern; CD4 >200 with suppressed viral load

New HAD diagnosis with marked functional impairment; suspected CNS OI; acute cognitive decline requiring urgent LP and imaging; CSF viral escape requiring inpatient ART optimization; unsafe home environment; inability to manage medications independently
